Leahy Teresa Curtin ⁎ Materials and Surface Science Institute, Chemical and Environmental Science Department, University of Limerick, Ireland ⁎ Corresponding author at: Materials and Surface Science Institute, National Technological Park, Limerick, Ireland. Tel.: +353 61 20298; fax: +353 61 202568. Graphical abstract Highlights ► The activity did not depend on metal dispersion, surface area nor particle size. ► The Pt based catalysts consistently produced less trans fatty acids. ► The trans content can be reduced by control of operating conditions. ► The reduction in trans formation was most significant for the Pt based catalysts. Selective hydrogenation of sunflower oil was tested using a variety of heterogeneous catalysts. The reaction was carried out in a batch reactor under different operating conditions. Palladium and platinum supported on Al2O3, ZrO2 and TiO2 were screened. A range of metal dispersions (6–69%) and loadings (0.3–3.9%) were studied for promotion of selectivity in cis C18:1. The catalysts were compared with a conventional Ni catalyst. The Pd catalysts were found to be much more active than the Ni catalyst. The Pt catalyst, while not as active as the Pd catalysts, produced lower trans fatty acids during hydrogenation. The level of trans could be further reduced by increasing the operating pressure to 10bar and reducing the reaction temperature to 100°C. The reduction in trans formation was most significant for the Pt based catalyst. The different catalysts prepared were shown to process a wide variety of different characteristics in terms of metal dispersion, surface areas, particle size, etc. However, this had little influence on the overall activity of the samples. The key issue in terms of activity was the catalyst metal content. Keywords Noble metal catalysts Hydrogenation of sunflower oil Trans fatty acids 1 Introduction Catalytic hydrogenation is a commonly used industrial process for modifying the chemical and physical characteristics of vegetable oils. The process results in increased oxidative stability and shelf life and produces material with desirable hardening characteristics for use in shortenings and confectionary products. The process involves the conversion of liquid oil to a solid or semi-solid product by means of a multi-phase catalytic reaction in the presence of hydrogen [1–4]. During the hydrogenation process a significant fraction of the naturally occurring cis double bonds are isomerised to trans fatty acids (TFAs). TFAs are associated with increased risk of coronary heart disease (CHD). Studies on dietary fat intake suggest a four- to five-fold higher risk of CHD per gram of TFA than per gram of saturated fat [5]. Several public health organisations have consequently recommended that the intake of TFA be lowered as much as possible [6]. Typically, hydrogenation is carried out in a three-phase semi batch reactor over a porous nickel catalyst between 1 and 6bar and around 170°C. The catalyst is suspended in the oil, brought to the required temperature, and hydrogen is then bubbled through this mixture, where the hydrogenation reaction commences. Activity and in particular selectivity to TFA is strongly influenced by transport of hydrogen to the active site which in turn is influenced by geometry and pore dimensions of the catalyst support. The TFA content from conventional industrial processes using Raney Nickel is typically 15–30% so technologies which can achieve the desired hardening characteristics with low TFA levels are of significant interest. Noble metal catalysts have been considered as viable alternatives to the present industrial Ni catalyst. The type of dispersed metal on the solid support has an influence on isomerisation. Schmidt [7] reported that, as an unavoidable side-reaction during hydrogenation, isomerisation can be affected by the active metal. This was also noted by other authors such as Allen and Kiess [8] and Bernas et al. [9]. Their studies have shown that isomerisation occurs readily on noble metals and therefore the choice of metal has an important influence on the hydrogenated oil's fatty acid profile. Studies have shown that these metals are much more active and in certain cases have a lower tendency to form trans fatty acids than Ni. Throughout the literature [9–17], the most commonly reported active catalysts are the noble metals, platinum (Pt) and palladium (Pd). The established order for increasing trans formation amongst all reported oil hydrogenation catalysts is: Pt<Rh<Ir<Ni<Pd<Cu [18]. The aim of the present study was to examine in detail the influence of the support and metal content on the catalytic properties of Pd and Pt for oil hydrogenation. The effect of operating conditions was also studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The precursor salts used in catalyst preparation were palladium chloride (PdCl2, 99.9%, Sigma–Aldrich) and hexachloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6·H2O, 99.9%, Sigma–Aldrich). To prepare a supported Pt (or Pd) catalyst by wet impregnation the following procedure was used: the required amount of hexachloroplatinic acid (or palladium chloride) was dissolved in excess water, approx. 50ml. The support (0.2g) was then added to the solution and the mixture was stirred constantly for 16h at room temperature. The impregnated catalyst was dried under reduced pressure at 90°C on a rotary evaporator. The resultant solid was dried for a further 2–3h at 80°C in an oven. Finally the catalyst was calcined in a furnace at 450°C for 5h in air. A series of catalysts were prepared for screening using the above methods; these included Pd and Pt supported on Al2O3 (Rhône-Poulenc), ZrO2 (Sigma–Aldrich) and TiO2 (Sigma–Aldrich). 2.2 Hydrogenation of sunflower oil The testing of catalysts for the hydrogenation of sunflower oil (Flora) was carried out using a 600ml Parr pressure reactor, model 4560 (Parr Instrument Co., Moline, IL, USA). Typically, 150mg of powdered catalyst (particle size 5–25μm) was placed in the reactor vessel and reduced in situ by passing hydrogen gas over it at 200°C for 2–3h. It was then cooled and the system purged with argon before the sunflower oil was introduced (100ml). The temperature of the system was increased gradually to 170°C (or 100°C) and hydrogen was then introduced. This point was referred to as “time=0”. The system was agitated using an impeller at a stirring rate of 400rpm (or 600rpm). The hydrogen pressure was maintained constant at 3bar (or 10bar) throughout the reaction. Oil samples were taken from the reactor every hour and the entire reaction time was 4h. Each sample was analysed for its iodine value (IV) according to EN ISO 3961 Wijs method [19]. The iodine value of an oil or fat is a measure of unsaturation and was used to monitor the activity of the catalysts. The fatty acid composition of the hydrogenated oils was determined by gas chromatography (GC). The triglycerides were first converted into their fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) according to ISO 5509:2000 [20]. The samples were analysed on a Varian Chromopack CP-3380 GC equipped with a flame ionisation detector using a SP-2560 (100m, 0.25mm ID, 0.2μm film thickness) coated fused silica capillary column (Restek, Bellefonte, PA). 2.3 Catalyst characterisation XRD patterns were obtained using a Philips X’Pert Pro X-ray diffractometer with nickel filtered KαCu radiation (λ =1.542Å) between the X-ray source angles of 10° and 70°. The specific surface area measurements and the pore size distributions of the catalytic materials were determined from N2 adsorption/desorption experiments at −196°C using a Micrometrics ASAP 2010 system. The pore volume and pore size distribution were calculated using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda theory from the adsorption isotherm. A Varian SpectrAA Atomic Absorption Spectrometer was used to measure the Pt and Pd contents of the prepared catalysts. The metal dispersion was measured using a dynamic pulse technique. Prior to analysis, the catalyst was reduced in flowing H2 (BOC Gases) at 300°C for 1h and then cooled to room temperature in nitrogen (or to 70°C for Pd based samples). A known volume of H2 was pulsed into the carrier gas and passed through the catalyst bed. Gas adsorption was measured by comparing the amount injected with the amount passing through the bed unadsorbed. The H2 was monitored using a TCD (thermal conductivity detector), operating at 80°C and 90mA. The amount adsorbed was determined by comparing the difference in areas under the peaks with saturated peaks. Assuming the stoichiometry of 1H atom per Pt atom the metal dispersion was calculated. A Jeol 2011 Transmission electron microscope was used to obtain high resolution images of the different catalysts. The imaging programme, Digital Micrograph™, was used to visualise and analyse digital image data from the electron microscope. The software was to calculate the average metal particle size by sampling at least 100 particles. 3 Results 3.1 Performance of different supports for the hydrogenation reaction Pd and Pt were impregnated on various oxide supports (ZrO2, TiO2 and Al2O3) in an effort to investigate the role of the catalyst support on the activity and the cis/trans selectivity. Table 1 lists the catalysts prepared, the metal content determined by AAS and the textural support properties. Each catalyst has been named based on the noble metal content (determined by AAS) and the support type. A range of surface areas (47–125m2 g−1) and pore diameters (35–107nm) can be seen for the different supports. The surface area and the corresponding pore characteristics of the Pd and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts were very similar to that of the support, indicating only a slight modification of the textural characteristics of the support following impregnation. The surface area of the alumina support was 125m2 g−1 and the average pore diameter was 35nm, signifying mesoporous characteristics. The ZrO2 based catalysts show a lower surface area (62m2 g−1) but a relatively large pore diameter of 107nm, while the TiO2 catalysts also presented a low surface area (47m2 g−1) and an average pore diameter of 50nm. For both of these supports there was a slight decrease in surface area and pore size with impregnation. The size of the Pt and Pd particles on the various supports was measured using both TEM and hydrogen chemisorption. The results of the analyses are also presented in Table 1 along with the metal dispersion. Hydrogen chemisorption is commonly used for measuring the dispersion of metals on supported catalysts. There are many advantages associated with the technique: it is simple, physical adsorption of H2 on the metal or support is unimportant, and adsorption on oxidised phases is negligible. However, there are some disadvantages including hydrogen chemisorption on surface impurities and in the case of palladium, the possible formation of bulk hydrides [21–23]. Therefore, in order to minimise the formation of hydrides on the Pd catalysts during H2 chemisorption, experimental measurements were carried out at a temperature of 70°C [24]. Although a relatively good comparison in particle size between the two techniques is observed, the TEM gave slightly higher results compared to the hydrogen chemisorption for all the catalysts analysed. Due to the limitations of the TEM's physical technique (contrast between metallic particles and the support), chemisorption data tend to provide more reliable information on average particle diameter, even though the relative uncertainty of the stoichiometric H/surface metal atom ratio must be recognised. The TiO2 and the ZrO2 catalysts showed low dispersion. The alumina supported catalysts showed the highest level of dispersion and the smallest particle sizes. The 0.74%Pd/Al2O3 catalyst gave rise to a dispersion of 54% and the 1.7%Pt/Al2O3 catalyst a dispersion of 68%. This is consistent with what is reported in the literature. Authors such as Boitiaux et al. [25] and Piqueras et al. [26] reported dispersion values between 50 and 60% for a series of 0.76%Pd on γ-Al2O3 catalysts using PdCl2 as the precursor salt. Fernández et al. [27] also reported particle sizes of 1.8nm for Pd supported on γ-Al2O3 using wet impregnation. The low dispersion observed with the TiO2 and ZrO2 is likely due to the nature of the support and its low interaction with the noble metals. All catalysts were tested under conditions similar to those used industrially; 170°C, 3bar hydrogen pressure and 400rpm agitation. A control run was carried out under these conditions in the absence of a catalyst and no hydrogenation was observed. The activity of the prepared catalysts was assessed by measuring the fall in iodine value (IV) of the oil with hydrogenation time. The unmodified sunflower oil showed an iodine value of 130 (IV at time=0). Fig. 1(a) presents the hydrogenation activity over the various supported palladium and platinum catalysts. The 1.98%Pt/TiO2 catalyst showed the highest activity indicated by the greatest reduction in IV over the 4h tested. However, it should be noted this catalyst also contained the highest amount of impregnated metal. The 1.45%Pd/ZrO2 demonstrated higher activity compared to the 1.28%Pd/TiO2 and the 1.36%Pt/ZrO2. The lowest activity was observed for the 0.74%Pd/Al2O3 catalyst reaching an IV of 80, while the 1.7%Pt/Al2O3 catalyst showed high hydrogenation activity, reaching an IV of 44 over the testing period. Overall, the differences in activity may not stem from the various supports but from the slight difference in metal loading as there seems to be a direct correlation between the fall in IV and metal loading for the catalyst tested. Fig. 1(b) presents the correlation between the fall of IV (over 4h) and metal content of catalysts. There is a strong relationship between the metal content and the activity. The more metal present, the greater the activity and this occurs irrespective of the support. Fig. 2(a) presents the evolution of reactants and products with time for the 0.74%Pd/Al2O3 catalyst. As the hydrogenation reaction proceeded a number of trends were observed. The linoleate (C18:2) component in the oil steadily decreased over the 4h. There was a corresponding increase in the formation of trans oleate (C18:1) with a slight increase in cis oleate up to 2h hydrogenation and after which a gradual decrease was observed. The rate of formation of stearate (C18:0) was very slow initially but increased after 3h. Fig. 2(b) presents the change in the oil composition with time for the 1.7%Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. A similar profile to the 0.74%Pd/Al2O3 is observed with a more rapid conversion of the C18:2 and a higher level of saturate (C18:0) formation. It is clear that the fatty acid composition changes with hydrogenation time, therefore to make a comparison between the performances of different catalysts it is important to compare them at a fixed activity level. Industrially, edible oils are often hydrogenated to an iodine value of 70, as this produces oil with a consistency suitable for the shortening and confectionary products, therefore in this work the performances of the catalysts were compared at an iodine value of 70. In Fig. 2(b) the dashed vertical line indicates the time where an IV of 70 occurs during hydrogenation and at this activity a trans isomer level of 32% and a saturate (C18:0) level of 19% were observed. There is no dashed line present in Fig. 2(a) because the 0.74%Pd/Al2O3 catalyst did not reach an IV of 70. The evolution of reactants and products with hydrogenation time for the ZrO2 and TiO2 catalysts were also determined. Fig. 3 compares the % trans and stearate at an IV of 70 for all prepared catalysts. The 0.74%Pd/Al2O3 catalyst did not reach an IV of 70 so the % trans and % stearate were not included. The results show that the Pd supported catalysts produce a higher level of trans fatty acids compared to the Pt supported catalysts. The 1.45%Pd/ZrO2 formed the highest level of trans, 45%, of all the catalysts tested, while the 1.98%Pt/TiO2 catalyst formed the lowest amount of trans, 30% at an IV of 70. Correspondingly the Pt based catalysts formed slightly more saturated fatty acids compared to the Pd catalysts at an IV of 70. The results suggest that metal chemistry and loading have a greater influence on catalyst activity and selectivity than the nature of the support. Indeed, despite the extremely variable surface areas, dispersion and particle sizes the results demonstrate that the support effect has little significant impact on the hydrogenation activity. Therefore, a more detailed study was carried out using different Pd and Pt amounts on an alumina support to study the influence of these metals and their contents on the performance of the catalyst during the oil hydrogenation process. 3.2 Effect of different metal loading on the hydrogenation reaction – palladium and platinum as active metals γ-Al2O3 was used as a support for varying levels of palladium and platinum which were tested for oil hydrogenation activity and selectivity in an effort to determine the influence of metal loading on the hydrogenation reaction. Table 2 lists the main structural characteristics and the metal content of the prepared catalysts. The surface areas and the corresponding pore characteristics of the Pd and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts were very similar to that of the support, indicating only a slight modification of the textural characteristics of the support following impregnation. The surface area of the alumina support was 125m2 g−1 and the average pore diameter was 35nm, signifying mesoporosity. The size of the Pt and Pd particles on the alumina support was measured using both TEM and hydrogen chemisorption. All the catalysts showed good dispersion between 50 and 69% which is consistent with that reported in literature [25–28]. From the results it is clear that as the metal loading increased, the dispersion reduced and the particle size increased. This trend of increasing metal loading resulting in a decrease in particle size is widely reported in the literature [10,29]. Fig. 4 presents the XRD patterns of the prepared Pd based catalysts. Weak diffraction peaks indicative of PdO were evident at 35 2θ for the 0.74%Pd/Al2O3 and the 2.1%Pd/Al2O3. For the Pt based catalysts (not shown) the only patterns observed were those of the alumina alone indicating a well dispersed catalyst. These observations are consistent with the results observed in Table 2 which shows the 0.74%Pd/Al2O3 and the 2.1%Pd/Al2O3 catalysts exhibiting the lowest dispersion and largest particle sizes of this series of catalysts. Fig. 5 presents the change in activity with time for the various loaded palladium and platinum supported on Al2O3 catalysts. All the catalysts tested were active for hydrogenation of sunflower oil. The 2.1%Pd/Al2O3 catalyst showed the highest activity since the IV dropped the most over time while the lower loaded 0.35%Pd/Al2O3 catalyst presented the lowest activity reaching an IV of 105 after 4h. The 0.74%Pd/Al2O3 catalyst reached an IV of 80 after the 4h. For the Pt based catalysts, Fig. 5(b), the 1.7%Pt/Al2O3 presented high hydrogenation activity, similar to the 3.86%Pt/Al2O3, reaching an IV of 44 after 4h hydrogenation. The least active of the Pt catalysts was the 0.85%Pt/Al2O3 (the lowest Pt metal loading), reaching an IV of 75 after 4h. Overall the Pd catalysts were more active than the Pt catalysts at comparable metal contents. Fig. 6 presents the initial fall in IV over the first hour of hydrogenation and its relationship with the metal loading. Increasing the amount of supported Pt resulted in increased activity, however the rate of this increase, levelled off somewhat at loading above 2wt% Pt. Although there are more active metal sites available for hydrogenation the limited level of H2 present in the oil means that the reaction rate is controlled by the dissolved H2 content and not the metal loading, therefore eventually reaching a plateau. A significant increase in activity was noted for each increase of the Pd loading. The graph illustrates that the Pd catalysts were more active than the Pt catalysts at similar metal loadings. Fig. 7(a)–(c) presents the change in the oil composition for the 0.35%Pd/Al2O3, 0.74%Pd/Al2O3 and 2.1%Pd/Al2O3 catalysts, respectively. It is evident from these graphs that the 2.1%Pd/Al2O3 was the most active since the linoleate (C18:2) completely reacted in less than 2h. Once the linoleate was consumed, a steady increase in stearate (C18:0) formation was observed, finally forming a very high level of saturate as the trans and cis C18:1 decreased. At an IV of 70, indicated by a dashed vertical line, the 2.1%Pd/Al2O3 catalyst formed 38% trans and 17% stearate. Very little activity was observed for the 0.35%Pd/Al2O3 catalyst and this can be seen in the negligible changes in its fatty acid profile shown in Fig. 7(a). Good activity was shown for the 0.74%Pd/Al2O3 catalyst reaching an IV of 80 after 4h reaction. This can be seen from Fig. 7(b) which shows a steady drop in the C18:2 concentration and a corresponding increase in the trans fatty acid content. No dashed line is included for the 0.35%Pd/Al2O3 and 0.74%Pd/Al2O3 catalysts as they did not reach an IV of 70 in the timeframe analysed. Fig. 8(a)–(c) compares the change in oil composition during hydrogenation using the 0.85%Pt/Al2O3, 1.7%Pt/Al2O3 and 3.86%Pt/Al2O3 catalysts, respectively. The 0.85%Pt/Al2O3 showed reasonably high hydrogenation activity with a steady drop in linoleate (C18:2) concentration over the 4h hydrogenation time. After the 4h reaction an IV of 75 was achieved, at this IV 30% trans and 14% stearate (C18:0) were recorded. The 3.86%Pt/Al2O3 showed high activity indicated by the rapid drop in linoleate (C18:2). At an IV of 70 this catalyst formed 36% trans and 19% stearate (C18:0). The 1.7%Pt/Al2O3 catalyst formed 32% trans and 19% saturates at a similar IV. Activity, measured as fall in iodine value and conversion of C18:2 was higher for the Pd catalysts. It is clear from the previous figures that the level of stearate and trans formed changes as a function of degree of hydrogenation. Therefore, the performances of the various catalysts were compared at a similar IV. Fig. 9 presents the selectivity of the various catalysts to the formation of trans and stearate at an iodine value of 80. An IV of 80 was chosen, as this represents a reasonable conversion and most of the catalysts tested could be included (with the exception of 0.35%Pd/Al2O3 which did not reach an IV of 80 during the testing timeframe). Also included in Fig. 9, for comparison purposes, is the Ni Pricat, the commercially used hydrogenation catalyst. This catalyst is composed of 22wt% Ni loaded on a silica support. The palladium catalysts, 0.74%Pd/Al2O3 and 2.1%Pd/Al2O3, generated more trans-isomers than the Pt based catalysts and the Ni Pricat at a comparable IVs. However, they formed very low levels of stearate. The Pt based catalysts produced the lowest level of trans at an IV 80, with 1.7%Pt/Al2O3 forming the lowest trans-isomers (26%). 3.3 Effects of operating conditions on the hydrogenation reaction The conditions employed during hydrogenation can determine the final properties of the oil. Commercial oil hydrogenation is usually carried out in a three-phase process (gas–liquid–solid), where several transport steps occur and interphase mass transport is important with particular emphasis on hydrogen transfer. Hydrogen is dissolved in the bulk oil, chemisorbs on the catalyst's surface and reacts from the adsorbed state. From this it can be said that the degree of the surface coverage of the adsorbed hydrogen is the dominating factor. The operating conditions can to a large extent control the mass transfer hence it is important to determine the optimum operating variables to achieve the desired end point. A study was carried out to investigate the effects of operating conditions on the hydrogenation reaction. Three catalysts, Ni Pricat, 2.1%Pd/Al2O3 and 1.7%Pt/Al2O3, were tested under two different sets of operating conditions with the aim of reducing the % trans. The standard operating conditions were 170°C, 3bar H2 pressure and 400rpm agitation. The operating variables were manipulated to increase the dissociated hydrogen on the catalysts by increasing the pressure during the reaction. The temperature of the reaction was also lowered since this is known to result in less trans fatty acid formation. The conditions used in this case were 100°C, 10bar H2 pressure and 600rpm agitation. Fig. 10 compares the performance of the three catalysts operated under the two different conditions at an IV 70 in terms of trans and stearate content. It is obvious across the three catalysts that increasing the pressure and lowering the temperature had a beneficial effect in terms of reducing trans formation. The trans content dropped from 33% to 23.5% for the Pricat catalyst which is a significant improvement. The 2.1%Pd/Al2O3 catalyst dropped to 31.2% from 38% and the 1.7%Pt/Al2O3 dropped to 19%. For all catalysts tested the stearate, C18:0, content increased during hydrogenation with the change in the operating variables. 4 Discussion From the above results it is clear that the active metal and the loading have an effect on the hydrogenation process. The results show that the Pd based catalysts are the most active compared to the commercial Ni Pricat and the Pt catalysts. These catalysts also form the lowest levels of stearate at comparative IVs. However, it was the Pt catalysts that showed the best selectivity towards cis isomer formation, resulting in the lowest level of trans-isomers produced at a similar IV, regardless of the support. The 1.7%Pt/Al2O3 catalyst presented a % trans value of 26% at an IV 80, compared to 44% trans for the 2.1%Pd/Al2O3 at a similar IV. This lower selectivity towards C18:1 trans for the Pt catalysts was accompanied by a slightly higher formation of saturated fatty acids (SFAs). The 1.7%Pt/Al2O3 catalyst formed 12% stearate at an IV 80 compared to 8% for the 2.1%Pd/Al2O3 catalyst. This phenomenon is reported in the literature [4,30,31]. The lower production of SFAs with the Pd catalysts is attributed to the difference in affinity of polyunsaturates and monounsaturates and their different adsorption strengths on the palladium. The polyunsaturates adsorb preferentially thus favoring the formation of monounsaturates (C18:1) rather than saturates (C18:0). It seems that the general feature of high trans content is inherent with palladium based catalysts. Changing the Pd metal content or the support, although influencing the activity, has little influence on the trans content. Investigators have reported on the higher activity of Pd catalysts over that of Ni and Pt based catalysts [27,29,32,33]. This was also observed for this study and can be seen in Fig. 11 . This figure presents the drop in IV per gram of metal per time for the indicated catalysts. From the chart it is clear that, per metal basis, Pd is the most active of the three metals. The Pt supported catalysts also present good activity but a little lower than the Pd supported catalysts. The commercial Ni Pricat catalyst presented the lowest level of activity per metal loading of the catalysts tested. The activity of the 3.86%Pt/Al2O3 was particularly low compared to the other Pt based catalyst. This is most likely linked to the relatively high level of Pt on the support and would indicate that increasing the active metal to these high levels results in the formation of sites either inaccessible to the reactant oil or produces particles that are not as active for the hydrogenation reaction. Indeed the optimum metal loading is about the 2wt%. The difference in the results for the various active metals most likely stems from the difference in the d-orbitals, which renders unique characteristics to each of these catalytic metals. The valency electrons of d nature are of fundamental importance for catalytic actions of metal surfaces. Transition elements have the possibility to change oxidation states and they can provide σ and π bonds with d and f internal orbitals. Chemisorption on metals involves the sharing of electron density from covalent bonds in the species being adsorbed. The strength of this bond is an important parameter for catalytic activity at metal surfaces. A difference in the d band for transition elements gives rise to different properties for the metals, hence the catalytic properties of each metal varies [22]. A number of investigators have reported how the effects of the support, dispersion and particle size of the metal can beneficially influence the hydrogenation process. Piqueras et al. [26] tentatively put forward the theory that smaller palladium particle sizes on supports can affect the cis/trans isomerisation reaction, forming lower levels of trans fatty acids. Nohair et al. [32], on the other hand found that the rate of hydrogenation was insensitive to the Pd particle size in the range 1.7–7.8nm. However, the larger Pd particles seemed to promote the cis to trans isomerisation, but this was not shown to be definitive. Our results indicate that the different characteristics of the supports of these oxides were not significant regardless of the variable surface area and pore diameter. For example the surface areas of the three different supports varied significantly (Al2O3 – 125m2 g−1, ZrO2 – 62m2 g−1 and TiO2 – 47m2 g−1) yet despite these differences the activities of the catalysts were simply linked to the content of the catalyst (see Fig. 1(b)). This could also indicate some inaccessibility of Pt, particularly if the Pt is located in pores that are relatively small compared to the oil molecule. So for example, in the case of the aluminium based catalysts, the average pore size was relatively small and the supported Pt particles are small (∼2nm). Therefore, some of this Pt may be inaccessible to the reacting oil. The ZrO2 and TiO2 supports have relatively larger average pore sizes therefore inaccessibility would not be as prominent. A difference in dispersion and particle size was also observed for this study, though no authoritative trend could be related to the hydrogenation or cis/trans isomerisation reaction. For example the catalysts prepared using Al2O3 as a support resulted in relatively high dispersion values of 50–60%. In contrast, the metal dispersions on the ZrO2 and the TiO2 catalysts were much less at values closer to 10%. Correspondingly, the particle sizes of the metals on the ZrO2 and the TiO2 catalysts were larger (12–20nm) compared to their Al2O3 counterparts (∼2nm). This implies that the level of exposed metal on the ZrO2 and the TiO2 based catalysts is much less. However, the activities of these catalysts for the hydrogenation of oil were comparable to the highly dispersed Al2O3 catalysts. This may indicate that of all the exposed metal available in the alumina catalysts only a part of it is available for reaction. This may simply mean that some of the metal particles are located in areas that are inaccessible to the reacting oil. Beneficial effects in terms of lowering the selectivity towards trans fatty acids were obtained when the operating conditions were varied. Increasing the pressure and agitation and decreasing the temperature resulted in the reduction of the formation of trans fatty acids for all catalysts. The modification in the operating conditions (lower temperature, higher H2 pressure) would have the effect of increasing the hydrogen concentration dissolved within the reacting oil and thus increasing the amount of hydrogen in contact with the catalyst surface. Coenen [34] and Heertje et al. [35] demonstrated conclusively that selectivity is caused by the preferential adsorption of polyunsaturates over that of the monounsaturates. Initially as the linoleate (C18:2) and oleate (C18:1) approach the catalysts surface, only one of the double bonds for each is adsorbed. If the hydrogen concentration is high, fast hydrogenation will occur on the adsorbed double bond and trans selectivity will be low. Veldsink et al. [18] reported that a high proportion of the linoleate (C18:2) will be converted into cis-monounsaturates, so that the specific isomerisation will also be low. If, on the other hand, when the pressure is low, the hydrogen coverage on the catalyst surface would also be low. In this instance linoleate (C18:2) will be bonded more strongly to the catalyst surface than the oleate (C18:1), therefore monopolising the surface and excluding the oleate (C18:1). As the hydrogen coverage is low the linoleate (C18:2) finds the time to split off a hydrogen atom from its reactive methylene group, thus becoming bonded with three carbon atoms to the catalyst. The second double bond is now brought closer to the surface and is bonded to it. This increases the bonding strength of the linoleate (C18:2). Under these conditions selectivity is found to be high as the polyunsaturates are hydrogenated first then the monounsaturates. Specific isomerisation is also found to be high resulting in a larger concentration of trans isomers in the final product. Of the three catalysts investigated under these conditions (high H2 pressure and low temperature) the most significant improvement in terms of reducing the trans content, was observed with the Pt base catalyst. The fall in trans was over 40% compared to normal operating conditions (3bar, 170°C). On the other hand, the 2.1%Pd /Al2O3 catalyst decreased from 38% to 31% (a drop of 18%) when operated under the new conditions, while the Ni catalyst dropped from 33% to 23.5% (a drop of 29%). In conjunction with this drop in trans, an increase in the stearate occurred for all catalysts. Therefore the Pt based catalysts seemed to be strongly influence by the increased dissolution of H2 within the reacting oil indicating increased reactive hydrogen at the catalytic surface under these conditions, with less formation of the trans isomer. Therefore the Pt based catalysts may be further tailored to reduce even further the formation of the trans formation by a combination of optimum exposure of the metal to the reacting oil and reaction conditions to optimise the reactive hydrogen. 5 Conclusion Pd based catalysts are more active than the Ni catalyst and Pt based catalysts for the hydrogenation of vegetable oil. However, the Pt based catalyst in general produced less trans fatty acids during hydrogenation. The level of trans reduced even further by increasing the operating pressure and reducing the reaction temperature. The reduction in trans formation was most significant for the Pt based catalyst. The different catalysts prepared were shown to process a wide variety of different characteristics in terms of metal dispersion, surface areas, particle size, etc.; however, this had little influence on the overall activity of the samples. The key issue in terms of activity was the catalyst metal content. coredata.dc:description: Selective hydrogenation of sunflower oil was tested using a variety of heterogeneous catalysts. The reaction was carried out in a batch reactor under different operating conditions. Palladium and platinum supported on Al2O3, ZrO2 and TiO2 were screened. A range of metal dispersions (6–69%) and loadings (0.3–3.9%) were studied for promotion of selectivity in cis C18:1. The catalysts were compared with a conventional Ni catalyst. The Pd catalysts were found to be much more active than the Ni catalyst. The Pt catalyst, while not as active as the Pd catalysts, produced lower trans fatty acids during hydrogenation. The level of trans could be further reduced by increasing the operating pressure to 10bar and reducing the reaction temperature to 100°C. The reduction in trans formation was most significant for the Pt based catalyst. The different catalysts prepared were shown to process a wide variety of different characteristics in terms of metal dispersion, surface areas, particle size, etc. However, this had little influence on the overall activity of the samples. The key issue in terms of activity was the catalyst metal content.
coredata.dc:title: Selective hydrogenation of sunflower oil over noble metal catalysts
